text: Paul, an apostle (not sent from men nor through the agency of man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised Him from the dead),
speaker: Narrator

text:
and all the brethren who are with me,
To the churches of Galatia:
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ,
speaker: Narrator

text: who gave Himself for our sins so that He might rescue us from this present evil age, according to the will of our God and Father,
speaker: Narrator

text: to whom be the glory forevermore. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am amazed that you are so quickly deserting Him who called you by the grace of Christ, for a different gospel;
speaker: Narrator

text: which is really not another; only there are some who are disturbing you and want to distort the gospel of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: But even if we, or an angel from heaven, should preach to you a gospel contrary to what we have preached to you, he is to be accursed!
speaker: Narrator

text: As we have said before, so I say again now, if any man is preaching to you a gospel contrary to what you received, he is to be accursed!
speaker: Narrator

text: For am I now seeking the favor of men, or of God? Or am I striving to please men? If I were still trying to please men, I would not be a bond-servant of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I would have you know, brethren, that the gospel which was preached by me is not according to man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it, but I received it through a revelation of Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have heard of my former manner of life in Judaism, how I used to persecute the church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it;
speaker: Narrator

text: and I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my contemporaries among my countrymen, being more extremely zealous for my ancestral traditions.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when God, who had set me apart even from my mother’s womb and called me through His grace, was pleased
speaker: Narrator

text: to reveal His Son in me so that I might preach Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately consult with flesh and blood,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went away to Arabia, and returned once more to Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then three years later I went up to Jerusalem to become acquainted with Cephas, and stayed with him fifteen days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I did not see any other of the apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now in what I am writing to you, I assure you before God that I am not lying.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was still unknown by sight to the churches of Judea which were in Christ;
speaker: Narrator

text: but only, they kept hearing, “He who once persecuted us is now preaching the faith which he once tried to destroy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they were glorifying God because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then after an interval of fourteen years I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking Titus along also.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was because of a revelation that I went up; and I submitted to them the gospel which I preach among the Gentiles, but I did so in private to those who were of reputation, for fear that I might be running, or had run, in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: But not even Titus, who was with me, though he was a Greek, was compelled to be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was because of the false brethren secretly brought in, who had sneaked in to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Jesus, in order to bring us into bondage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we did not yield in subjection to them for even an hour, so that the truth of the gospel would remain with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from those who were of high reputation (what they were makes no difference to me; God shows no partiality)—well, those who were of reputation contributed nothing to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the contrary, seeing that I had been entrusted with the gospel to the uncircumcised, just as Peter had been to the circumcised
speaker: Narrator

text: (for He who effectually worked for Peter in his apostleship to the circumcised effectually worked for me also to the Gentiles),
speaker: Narrator

text: and recognizing the grace that had been given to me, James and Cephas and John, who were reputed to be pillars, gave to me and Barnabas the right hand of fellowship, so that we might go to the Gentiles and they to the circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: They only asked us to remember the poor—the very thing I also was eager to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Cephas came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he stood condemned.
speaker: Narrator

text: For prior to the coming of certain men from James, he used to eat with the Gentiles; but when they came, he began to withdraw and hold himself aloof, fearing the party of the circumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the Jews joined him in hypocrisy, with the result that even Barnabas was carried away by their hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I saw that they were not straightforward about the truth of the gospel, I said to Cephas in the presence of all, “If you, being a Jew, live like the Gentiles and not like the Jews, how is it that you compel the Gentiles to live like Jews?
speaker: Narrator

text: “We are Jews by nature and not sinners from among the Gentiles;
speaker: Narrator

text: nevertheless knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the Law but through faith in Christ Jesus, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, so that we may be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the Law; since by the works of the Law no flesh will be justified.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if, while seeking to be justified in Christ, we ourselves have also been found sinners, is Christ then a minister of sin? May it never be!
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I rebuild what I have once destroyed, I prove myself to be a transgressor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For through the Law I died to the Law, so that I might live to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been crucified with Christ; and it is no longer I who live, but Christ lives in me; and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself up for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not nullify the grace of God, for if righteousness comes through the Law, then Christ died needlessly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You foolish Galatians, who has bewitched you, before whose eyes Jesus Christ was publicly portrayed as crucified?
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the only thing I want to find out from you: did you receive the Spirit by the works of the Law, or by hearing with faith?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you so foolish? Having begun by the Spirit, are you now being perfected by the flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did you suffer so many things in vain—if indeed it was in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, does He who provides you with the Spirit and works miracles among you, do it by the works of the Law, or by hearing with faith?
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so Abraham believed God, and it was reckoned to him as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, be sure that it is those who are of faith who are sons of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel beforehand to Abraham, saying, “All the nations will be blessed in you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then those who are of faith are blessed with Abraham, the believer.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as many as are of the works of the Law are under a curse; for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who does not abide by all things written in the book of the law, to perform them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that no one is justified by the Law before God is evident; for, “The righteous man shall live by faith.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Law is not of faith; on the contrary, “He who practices them shall live by them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the Law, having become a curse for us—for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree”—
speaker: Narrator

text: in order that in Christ Jesus the blessing of Abraham might come to the Gentiles, so that we would receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brethren, I speak in terms of human relations: even though it is only a man’s covenant, yet when it has been ratified, no one sets it aside or adds conditions to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the promises were spoken to Abraham and to his seed. He does not say, “And to seeds,” as referring to many, but rather to one, “And to your seed,” that is, Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: What I am saying is this: the Law, which came four hundred and thirty years later, does not invalidate a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to nullify the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the inheritance is based on law, it is no longer based on a promise; but God has granted it to Abraham by means of a promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why the Law then? It was added because of transgressions, having been ordained through angels by the agency of a mediator, until the seed would come to whom the promise had been made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a mediator is not for one party only; whereas God is only one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is the Law then contrary to the promises of God? May it never be! For if a law had been given which was able to impart life, then righteousness would indeed have been based on law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Scripture has shut up everyone under sin, so that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before faith came, we were kept in custody under the law, being shut up to the faith which was later to be revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Law has become our tutor to lead us to Christ, so that we may be justified by faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all of you who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free man, there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham’s descendants, heirs according to promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I say, as long as the heir is a child, he does not differ at all from a slave although he is owner of everything,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he is under guardians and managers until the date set by the father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also we, while we were children, were held in bondage under the elemental things of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the fullness of the time came, God sent forth His Son, born of a woman, born under the Law,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that He might redeem those who were under the Law, that we might receive the adoption as sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you are sons, God has sent forth the Spirit of His Son into our hearts, crying, “Abba! Father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you are no longer a slave, but a son; and if a son, then an heir through God.
speaker: Narrator

text: However at that time, when you did not know God, you were slaves to those which by nature are no gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now that you have come to know God, or rather to be known by God, how is it that you turn back again to the weak and worthless elemental things, to which you desire to be enslaved all over again?
speaker: Narrator

text: You observe days and months and seasons and years.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fear for you, that perhaps I have labored over you in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: I beg of you, brethren, become as I am, for I also have become as you are. You have done me no wrong;
speaker: Narrator

text: but you know that it was because of a bodily illness that I preached the gospel to you the first time;
speaker: Narrator

text: and that which was a trial to you in my bodily condition you did not despise or loathe, but you received me as an angel of God, as Christ Jesus Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where then is that sense of blessing you had? For I bear you witness that, if possible, you would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So have I become your enemy by telling you the truth?
speaker: Narrator

text: They eagerly seek you, not commendably, but they wish to shut you out so that you will seek them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it is good always to be eagerly sought in a commendable manner, and not only when I am present with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: My children, with whom I am again in labor until Christ is formed in you—
speaker: Narrator

text: but I could wish to be present with you now and to change my tone, for I am perplexed about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell me, you who want to be under law, do you not listen to the law?
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by the bondwoman and one by the free woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the son by the bondwoman was born according to the flesh, and the son by the free woman through the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is allegorically speaking, for these women are two covenants: one proceeding from Mount Sinai bearing children who are to be slaves; she is Hagar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this Hagar is Mount Sinai in Arabia and corresponds to the present Jerusalem, for she is in slavery with her children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Jerusalem above is free; she is our mother.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: And you brethren, like Isaac, are children of promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as at that time he who was born according to the flesh persecuted him who was born according to the Spirit, so it is now also.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But what does the Scripture say?
“Cast out the bondwoman and her son,
For the son of the bondwoman shall not be an heir with the son of the free woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, brethren, we are not children of a bondwoman, but of the free woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was for freedom that Christ set us free; therefore keep standing firm and do not be subject again to a yoke of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold I, Paul, say to you that if you receive circumcision, Christ will be of no benefit to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I testify again to every man who receives circumcision, that he is under obligation to keep the whole Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have been severed from Christ, you who are seeking to be justified by law; you have fallen from grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we through the Spirit, by faith, are waiting for the hope of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision means anything, but faith working through love.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were running well; who hindered you from obeying the truth?
speaker: Narrator

text: This persuasion did not come from Him who calls you.
speaker: Narrator

text: A little leaven leavens the whole lump of dough.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have confidence in you in the Lord that you will adopt no other view; but the one who is disturbing you will bear his judgment, whoever he is.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I, brethren, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still persecuted? Then the stumbling block of the cross has been abolished.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wish that those who are troubling you would even mutilate themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you were called to freedom, brethren; only do not turn your freedom into an opportunity for the flesh, but through love serve one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the whole Law is fulfilled in one word, in the statement, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you bite and devour one another, take care that you are not consumed by one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I say, walk by the Spirit, and you will not carry out the desire of the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the flesh sets its desire against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh; for these are in opposition to one another, so that you may not do the things that you please.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the deeds of the flesh are evident, which are: immorality, impurity, sensuality,
speaker: Narrator

text: idolatry, sorcery, enmities, strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, disputes, dissensions, factions,
speaker: Narrator

text: envying, drunkenness, carousing, and things like these, of which I forewarn you, just as I have forewarned you, that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
speaker: Narrator

text: gentleness, self-control; against such things there is no law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now those who belong to Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we live by the Spirit, let us also walk by the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us not become boastful, challenging one another, envying one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brethren, even if anyone is caught in any trespass, you who are spiritual, restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness; each one looking to yourself, so that you too will not be tempted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bear one another’s burdens, and thereby fulfill the law of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone thinks he is something when he is nothing, he deceives himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each one must examine his own work, and then he will have reason for boasting in regard to himself alone, and not in regard to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: For each one will bear his own load.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who is taught the word is to share all good things with the one who teaches him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be deceived, God is not mocked; for whatever a man sows, this he will also reap.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who sows to his own flesh will from the flesh reap corruption, but the one who sows to the Spirit will from the Spirit reap eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us not lose heart in doing good, for in due time we will reap if we do not grow weary.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, while we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, and especially to those who are of the household of the faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: See with what large letters I am writing to you with my own hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who desire to make a good showing in the flesh try to compel you to be circumcised, simply so that they will not be persecuted for the cross of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who are circumcised do not even keep the Law themselves, but they desire to have you circumcised so that they may boast in your flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But may it never be that I would boast, except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For neither is circumcision anything, nor uncircumcision, but a new creation.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those who will walk by this rule, peace and mercy be upon them, and upon the Israel of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on let no one cause trouble for me, for I bear on my body the brand-marks of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, brethren. Amen.
speaker: Narrator
